reviewText:
Let me go on record to say that this game is fun.
It has some good gamemodes, some good combat, and overall, it's a very good counter-strike knockoff.
then the problems start.
First: this game installs a keylogger. THAT'S ‚ô•‚ô•‚ô•‚ô•ING RIGHT. IT INSTALLS A 3RD-PARTY KEYLOGGER FOR ANTI-CHEAT MEASURES. It's also nearly impossible to remove, unless you extremely specifically remove something from System32, then from Regedit, but i'm not even going to try.
Second: The company that made bought the rights to this game filled it up with weapons that you have to buy for... with real. world. money. Here's the best part: the weapons have better stats, but disappear from your inventory after a while. You know what that means? A Paytowin FPS.
Even if they didn't have other stats, they're just retextures of other items, for example, you could have a normal smoke grenade, or get a colored one for an additional fee.
Personally, i only installed this to get the black rose in TF2, but found myself playing it more than expected. I uninstalled it several months ago, and just now found out about the keylogger.
DON'T INSTALL THIS GAME. NOT EVEN FOR THE BLACK ROSE. IT'S NOT WORTH THE RISK.

reviewText:
First off, don't get fooled by my played hours, I've been playing it way before it was avaiable on steam but I didn't touch it since around 1.5 years. I would estimate that my played hours are somewhere around 3k, I've also participated in 2 tournaments. I would still love this game and recommend it to everyone and their grandma if Aeria wouldn't have messed up AVA like they did.

AVA was a great game back when ijji published it, it had great potential. The maps are great, nothing to complain about here. You could buy Weapons, Grenades and Armor for ingame money. You would get money relatively slow, but once you hit 50-60k ‚Ç¨ you could buy a decent, permanent weapon and that's pretty much all you needed. You also need money to repair that weapon and buy parts for your weapon that need to get replaced regularly. Getting 50-60k could take up to 1-2 months, depending on how much you played. You could still spend real money on weapons in order to get them immediately. It still was not pay to win at all. The graphics were actually decent for a F2P game. You would encounter hackers from time to time, depending on whether there were any free hacks out there or not.

Ever since Aeria games took over things changed. Their biggest failure was the removal of permanent weapons, which ultimately made the game pay to win. You could only buy weapons for 30 days, then they expired. The price of a decent weapon was still around 50-60k, and I guess you already see that this is a huge problem. If you don't play 3-4 hours per day you won't be able to get 50-60k per month, that means you have to play with the standard weapons which are not entirely useless, but you would never beat someone who is on the same skill level as you with a standard weapon while he uses his expensive rifle. This also meant that old players will always have an advantage over new players, because they still have their permanent weapons.

The thing is, you may think that the publisher should have no influence on the content of the game, since they are only publishing, but not making it. Redduck is actually making the game, and they do so for several other regions such as Japan/China/Korea. All of those regions still have permanent weapons. In fact, Aeria denied to have anything to do with the change from permanent to timed weapons, but we actually contacted someone from Redduck who told us that they were against that change, but Aeria insisted.

The next point are hackers. Aeria implemented a new anti cheat engine that doesn't do its job at all. There were times where you would run into a hacker every 2-3 games. I can't tell you how it is in its current state tho, since I haven't played since quite some time.

By the way, Aeria introduced the Tiered Spender" where you would get additional rewards depending on how much money you spend on their game. That's a nice concept
date: but the thing is that many of those additional rewards are permanent weapons
recommended: which is another aspect that makes it pay to win. Just to give you an idea on what you have to spend for a permanent weapon: In one of those tiered spenders you would get a permanent weapon starting at 7999 AP(a little more than 60‚Ç¨) and ending at 29999 AP(around 210‚Ç¨).\n\nThis is coming from someone who sometimes played this game all day long

reviewText:
Be aware of Aeria Games. They are a large f2p game publisher with many titles, and many genres; Mostly fps and mmorpg. They are known for their numerous pay-to-win models, where those to throw cash away to buy powerful guns for use on those that haven't spent anything. They intice more people into playing their games by partnering up with other companies and creating promotional content, i.e. the black rose in Team Fortress 2.

AVA was not always in the hands of aeria games, and when it wasn't it was a generic fps that was great for a few minutes of brainless shooting. Now it's exactly the same thing, only with a pay-to-win scheme along with many hackers who wish to get their own overpowered slaughterhouse feel without paying.

Not worth your time to download. In fact, I would recomend against downloading, as it will install a rootkit for anti-cheating purposes that will cause many problems and is a pain in the neck to remove.

reviewText:
First of all, I have been playing this game for 5 years and I have witnessed the decline of this game.

To start of with the positives:

+ Good graphics.
+ Wide selection of weapons.
+ Wide selection of maps and game modes.
+ You used to be able to play this game for hours on end and not get bored.


Now for the negatives:

- The most cancerous community you can ever imagine. Full of 12 year olds who spam constantly and cry about pretty much everything, they single-handedly destroy this game without the following negatives being taken into account.

- No functioning mute button which is really needed with this community.

- Cheaters, they tend to come in waves when public cheats are released. Think cheaters in games such as CSGO are a problem? There is probably a 75% chance that you will face at least one cheater in the Matchmaking channel each game you queue up for - unfortunately that figure is not greatly exaggerated and that is only considering the kids running around with blatant wall hacks and 1 hit kill cheats.

- Terrible publisher, they honestly do not give a fk about what the community wants unless it affects their income in a positive way. Sure, I understand it is a business, but not investing in a functioning anti-cheat, and instead focusing on the new tier-spender (a pay-to-win model) to satisfying those credit card whales is not the way to maintain a game.

- Non-functioning anti-cheat, it's clearly not doing its job properly, and it gives random errors to legit players such as myself causing my game to crash for no reason.

- Free-to-play, you'd think this would be a positive, but any kid that gets banned cheating can easily make a new account and farm it to a level in a few hours which allows them back into matchmaking.

- Lag, this game has two servers to serve 6 continents; the EU server is supposed to support Europe, Africa and Asia whereas the NA server is supposed to support North America, South America and Oceania. It is not uncommon to face teams with 200+ pings on their closest server, and this game does not have an effective IP-restriction for those countries for which the license does not cover.

- Hit registration, if you play CSGO you've probably heard the common quote 'Volvo pls fix 64 tick servers', and guess what, AVA is a significant downgrade on those servers, I believe somewhere in the region of 16 tick servers. This coupled with extreme laggers (the average ping in EU is probably around 70 and over 150 in NA) leads to countless frustrating encounters where you hit people first on your screen but end up dying behind a wall to a 300 ping BR.

- RNG elements, in a competitive FPS, you would expect RNG (random number generation) to be kept to a minimum, but this game has shooting mechanics which revolve around RNG. First is bloom (how much the bullets spread while spraying) which is fine to have as RNG, but the other is damage - I have been in countless situations where I have head shot someone with a Para (one of the highest damage rifles which is usually a 1 hit head shot) but then die because he didn't die but sprayed 2 AK47 bullets (a lower damage rifle) into my stomach. In short, head shots are not rewarded sufficiently in this game.

- Updates, in short, there is a lack of new content in new updates, it revolves around the pay-to-play whales where they are given new weapons to pay for (and at an obscene amount too).


Do not waste your time with this game, the community is pure cancer, they are the most stupid people you will ever come across in your life. One last thing you should know is that even if this game has 5000 active players (which is a very high estimate), the most recent public cheat had something like 3500+ downloads if I recall correctly.

reviewText: Playing this game for about five years going on six and seeing the different changes that have affected this game makes me ashamed of how long I've played this game, I have developed many perspectives for this game. Playing when IJJI had the game was when A.V.A was at its prime, back when the guns actually took skill to use, and how the competitive scene was just being born. But ever since Aeria Games has taken over the game, they have reduced the game to its limit. Milking every dollar they could make, removal of permanent guns and the implementation of timed weapons. Poor server maintenance, etc. First off this game is a fast paced, intense action first person shooter. Second the guns in this game are well made considering most of the guns are based off real guns. (excluding Mega Capsules, Blue tickets, Red Tickets, Etc.) Third, the maps are OKAY, not well made, it's basic maps, some maps are so outdated that they don't even bother fixing the glitches/bugs in most of the maps. (but the maps that are played the most are updated a lot.) Fourth, this games graphics are fairly outdated for the North American version (UAVA), but seeing what the future updates will bring forth has made me more interested in this game. Such as HD textures. Currently in TAVA (Taiwan AVA) they have HD Textures which are considered a huge thing. Fifth, is the competitive scene, back in 2009-2012 the competitive scene was at its best. ieSF was a huge contribution to the competitive scene, they made the players strive towards perfection at this game. But sadly ieSF has stopped including A.V.A in their games list, because of lack of players in the competitive scene. Many of you might know Skadoodle of team iBuyPower from CS:GO, he has played this game professionally and has competed in ieSF, considering this is the first game that he ever played competitively and has achieved the most in. It is sad how the players quit because of the lack of competition because poor anti-cheat, poor game design, etc. All the things I have listed here are mostly cons of why I don't recommend this game. And now I will list the Pros of this game, there are a few dedicated players willing to do whatever it takes to make this game better and improve the amount of players, to have a permanent gun in this game, you had to be playing before they removed the permanent option. If you live near the servers, (Example: Canada) you will have at least 1 ping or 2 depending if you have good internet or not, this game is a really good game to help your aim. It's easy to warm up for games like CS:GO, it will make your aim better, you could have fun playing this game if you play with friends. That pretty much it. Aside from the fact that the people installing this game just for the Black Rose" knife in TF2 and then uninstalling this game right after. It installs a keylogger into your system
date: but it does nothing. I promise you it doesn't do anything to your PC. But uninstalling it without playing it is stupid in my opinion. At least play the game
recommended: who knows? Maybe you will end up liking the game and maybe pay money to actually get permanent weapons. Overall my final verdict for this game is 6.5/10

This game used to be good before Aeria Games made it extremely pay 2 win with huge microtransactions.

reviewText:
Error: Suspicious program detected! Close all other programs you have running and restart the game.

It comes in a small window with fancied up window titles such as ‚òÖ------S-e-c-u-r-i-t-y------a-l-e-r-t------‚òÖ (it's randomised) and an all but dodgy picture of a private investigator holding a magnifying glass.

It doesn't tell you which program is suspicious, but instead asks you to submit a logfile that is not humanly readable, assumably with data about your running processes. At this point I wonder, why even ask? They already sniffed through your system.

Terrible and non-functional anti-cheat vaporware crap that needs to be killed with fire before it breeds.

This DLC for Uninstallation Simulator 2014 does not require the base game to be uninstalled.

reviewText:
Product received for free

TL:DR: Stay away from this game.

Here's a little story:
Back in 2009, a little game named Alliance of Valiant Arms came out. The ad I saw on TV mentioned that I didn't need a great PC to run it and it had amazing graphics (close to Modern Warfare 2 graphics.). I've played it, loved it, made a lot of friends. The game was great.

However, there was a small problem. The publishers never gave a ‚ô•‚ô•‚ô•‚ô•. The original publisher, ijji, tried to control the hacking situation (and failed), but they still kept the game Free2Play and not Pay2Win.

Fast forward a few years, Aeria Games is the new publisher. If you know Aeria Games, you know how ‚ô•‚ô•‚ô•‚ô•ed you are if you play their games. Aeria is now trying to milk as much money as they can from the players (which they call Customers and not Players). They removed the Key Features of the game: the graphics were downgraged (so the game kinda looks like ‚ô•‚ô•‚ô•‚ô• now), they removed some ingame currencies (and replaced them with real money currencies), they downgraded the servers, they somehow made the game lag on every computer (even if you've got 4 GTX 1080 TI's, you won't run it without constant FPS drops) and they let the Hacking situation explode (note that the influx of cheaters was when they removed the key features of the game, it was the player's way to protest).

This was a great game, I've invested around 2000 hours on multiple accounts, and it's sad to see how the game was brutally murdered by a company that doesn't care about it.
This game will soon join the graveyard of games that Aeria Games bought, exploited and closed.

reviewText: My Grandfather smoked his whole life. I was about 10 years old when my mother said to him, 'If you ever want to see your grandchildren graduate, you have to stop immediately.'. My mother said to me- 'Don't ever smoke. Please don't put your family through what your Grandfather put us through. I agreed. At 28
date: I have never touched a cigarette. I must say
recommended: I feel a very slight sense of regret for never having done it
hoursPlayed: because this game gave me cancer anyway."

In the good day of ijji, this game was the best free-to-play fps on the market. Unfortunatly, the compagny gone bankrupt and this game is now manage by aeria wich is the one of the worst money-hungry publisher on the planet.

The bad:
All weapon used to be permanant, wich was nice for a free-to-play game, aeria changed that. GIVE US PERM WEAPON BACK!
There used to be an update every month, now its more like every holiday.
It cost around $200~300 to get some weapons with the tired spender program, wich is too much.
Servers are crap and I get net lag even with 5~10 ping
Game moderators are mostly absent and support is bad with at best copy/paste robot response.
Most weapon you can buy with in-game currency got nerfed over time.
Broken in-game chat filter, that is too restrictive and unconfigurable.

The good:
Hackers are almost non-existant right now and the only hacker I come across from time to time is a fun" hacker. (if that make sense)
Nostalgia if you are like me and played for 4~5 years.

Overall
date: I cannot recommend this game to a new player in its current state. If aeria change

reviewText:
Holy ‚ô•‚ô•‚ô•‚ô•, even just getting the Black Rose was torture. So first I had to download it which took like 30 minutes, which is fine. BUT THEN, I had to download another part, which took like 2 hours, which is not ok. After FINALLY downloading it, the game crashes on startup. I have to restart Steam to finally play what I was hoping to be a decent shooter, at least good enough to make getting the knife worthwhile. Upon starting up, the framerate was great, and the tutorial was good, which made me have high hopes. I have to play an online match to get my Black Rose. After playing the match I want to kill myself. I am instantly met with like 30 bots on my team I was like (not a good sign), and one actual player. The enemies 30 bots and two players come up to assault us, and it is the biggest ‚ô•‚ô•‚ô•‚ô•‚ô•torm I have ever experienced. To sum it up, its like a Clash of Clans attack, where the enemy, instead of having defenses, has the same amount of troops you do. And everything dies in one hit. Sound fun yet? I had to suffer through a ten minute deathmatch of them spawncamping and one shotting everything with sniper rifles. We lost, but I FINALLY, FINNNALLLLY got my really ‚ô•‚ô•‚ô•‚ô•ing well deserved Black Rose for TF2, and am about to go try it out. But at what cost?



Unless you really want the knife, do not suffer through this.

reviewText:
If you are looking for an honest review other than the tf2 achievement reward:
I have been playing this game since ijji was the owner. I have had many accounts since. I will enlist SOME pros and cons in this game.  (this is my opinion) :

Pros :
-Graphics,
-Variety of gameplay modes, maps and weapons,
-Strategic weapon classes,
-Few hackers (at least from what i can see),
-Permanent weapons are back now ( but the AP ones are still overpowered )
-Regular updates with new content, maps and modes,

Cons :
-Pay to win, the best weapons, armor and equipment are going to cost you money (some weapons cost 20 Euros/dollars ), unless you are willing to spend half your time making free ap through surveys,
-Stupid weapon names,
-The amount of people who play this game has dropped. Many experienced players who will crush noobs,
-There are no more beginner rooms, can be offputting for beginners,
-Cpu heavy,
-Half of the players use AP weapons, which seems unfair,
-Many glitches when playing coop,
-Aeria will close down your account if you are inactive for too long ( a year I think )


Other :
-For some reason some of the local files may appear as viruses through your antivirus,
-The game takes ages to load even though I have a decent enough rig

Overall, AVA is a good FPS, I find that the gameplay is great but i also think that Aeria could make much better by not making it a pay to win ...

7/10

reviewText:
I've played AVA since it first came out in 2006.

Firstly to all of you who have loved and played the classic AVA for years and then came on Steam only to see bad reviews and are confused, ALL the bad reviews are from ignorant people who just downloaded and uninstalled the game for some promotion, and more bad reviews by bitter people who were disappointed that AVA stopped giving out permanent weapons for free so easily because of moving from ijji to Aeria... yes that's right you can STILL get permamnent weapons for free, just use the capsule shop for blue money! Anyway games like PlanetSide 2 are even worse for being strict on weapons, it is so P2W. AVA is not P2W, and even if you want to pay it's not expensive.

For people  who haven't played AVA and are thinking about it, I highly recommend it. AVA is extremely lightweight for such a seemingly heavy game, so it is good for most non-gaming computers too, I used to play it all the time on a rubbish computer. I'ts programming is good and very enjoyable to play, it's one of the only first-person shooter games where I get 200+FPS. I love AVA it's a pure classic, I highly recommend it. Convoy Runaway is my favourite mode on it, and there are so many different maps and modes there is something for everyone to enjoy...

Bottom line AVA is a great game, it should be respected and given better consideration big time. I enjoy this game more than PlanetSide 2, PlanetSide 2 is too focused on one game mode of map domination, when u just want really fun arcade kill em up modes AVA is for you. I especially like it A LOT more than TF2, personally I really dislike TF2.

Rate this review up so that everyone can actually see a fair and original review instead of the hundreds of TF2 players who all write EXACTLY the same thing! e.g. 1 install 2. get knife for tf2, 3 uninstall... lololol

I used to play this game, A LOT, sometimes spending till about 6:30 am ( yes that exact time ) and I've made a guide for all the newbies to the game, I hope you find it helpful :) ( PS. I only installed this game because I saw a friend of mine play it when I first downloaded steam )

Step 1. Download the game

Step 2. Download the 69 patches that come along with it

Step 3. Make an Account

Step 4. Launch the game

Step 5. Relaunch the game because it crashed

Step 6. Relaunch the game because it crashed

Step 7. Relaunch the game because it crashed

Step 8. The game finally works and you start playing

- Might as well play COD

- Community is basically a COD community. (Direspectful, ECT.)

- They try to lure people to play this game when they just needs major fixing to the game, like make a whole new game or something. which they try to fix and I praise for (They did a survey, although if they listen to peoples results is up to them).

reviewText:
Played this game a few years ago trough ijii, 'Neat FPS game, probably best free to play fps game ever' was in my thoughts, tons of fun, good sounds, gameplay, graphic style(wich works on alot of PC's), game modes, how weapons fire, community and all, pretty much amazing. Kinda took a long break and when i get it back, guess what, aeria games hosting now, which ruined a lot of things(if you know aeria games pretty well, i don't have to explain), which also led to a drop in player base, also the number of hackers increased.
Pay to win  would describe its current situation, so if you want to get real deep in it, or just keep your favourite weapons you can't without real money, which i advise you to not throw into those money grabbing A-holes of Aeria Games.

But for the heck of the old enjoyment, or if you want to just get some random fun, from time to time, i still recommend this game, because practicaly, this game is great, the current publisher is the problem. If it will be changed, problem solved, unfortunately that seems unlikely though :(

reviewText:
Warning: this review has been re-uploaded intentionally to not only update new info, but to remove previous ratings due to the review's harsh judgement. I will be reviewing this on my own opinions, although some other opinions are quite the same as mine. Also, I have only played this game for at least a several hours, and has been a long time since then. As a result, the review may not be accurate. Regardless, you've been warned.

A.V.A - Alliance of Valiant Arms is a First-Person Shooter where you choose from one of many classes and..well..kill people. Sound familiar? If many answered Call of Duty, Team Fortress 2, or even Counter Strike, you'd likely be here because it looked cool and all. Not all is what it seems."

Okay
date: before we dip ourselves into the bad parts of this pool
recommended: let's go over the good things I have to say of the game.\n\n+ Despite me not liking the artwork this game displays on the store or even the logo
hoursPlayed: the graphics in this game are pretty good
voteText: if not decent. And I must say a lot of effort was put into making the game look nice.\n\n+ The game functions well
helpfulPercent: and I haven't suffered a single crash.\n\n+ Hackers about? Not likely. Despite all what people said about "this game is infested with lifeless hackers!"
votesHelpful: I am still having a legitimate experience without suffering any ‚ô•‚ô•‚ô•‚ô•‚ô•‚ô•‚ô•t such as aimbots
votesFunny: or any cheats actually. So either they all were ‚ô•‚ô•‚ô•‚ô•‚ô•‚ô• at some snipers doing some 360 no-scopes
commentsCount: or just wanted to start some rumors on this already down-hill of a game. So in short
column16: not many hackers. That's a plus.\n\nNow
column17: let's list some of the major issues this game has.\n\n- This game is very Pay-to-Play influenced. Instead of selling skins and all
column18: there are actual weapons being sold as micro-transactions which aren't micro at all. Do you expect me to pay 50$ for a single pack of weapons from a Free-to-Play game? No
column19: I wouldn't. It's worse as it encourages people to put money into the game
column20: most recently with the "Welcome Pack 2016" update.\n\n- The next problem is one people always complain about. People from Team Fortress 2 flock to this game in order to obtain a Spy knife reskin known as "The Black Rose"
column21: a good looking one at that
column22: and was pretty cool before Tough Break came along. To obtain this knife
column23: you simply had to get an achievement in-game. Simple
column25: this is where the second flaw comes into play. For some reason..and I mean for some reason
column26: the developers thought it was a good idea to prevent you from obtaining any achievements until you beat the entire tutorial. You know what that means? You have to sit through an hour or two learning of the game's way of school. And no
column27: not just the basic gameplay. I literally mean everything. Only then are you qualified to obtain achievements and obtain "The Black Rose". At least
column28: in my experience. When I completed my first round
column29: nothing. However as soon as a beat the tutorial completely
column31: only one was the tutorial while the other three was from that previous match. As of me last playing in early 2015
column32: there has yet to be a fix for it other than playing the tutorial like intended.\n\n- The holy grail to it all is the game's installment. It's files are quite..cruel to other files. In the game's installment
column33: an "anti-cheat" program is installed that instantly deletes any and all files that the program finds either interfering with the game
column34: and/or because it can. Most cases it was because it could. Why? My Team Fortress 2 graphics looked like they came straight from a missing textured mess from Garry's Mod
column35: and I had to re-install the entire game to fix it. Again
column36: this was in my experience. Just uninstall A.V.A once you get what you want from it.\n\nNow with all the major issues out of the way
column37: let's tackle the lesser problem I have with the game.\n\n* The game when launched by steam
column38:
launches it's own launcher. It's a small gripe I have. There isn't any real settings to change in said launcher last time I launched it besides maybe screen sizes or fullscreen toggle.


Overall

column40: it isn't that bad as people say. The gameplay is decent and the graphics look decent. Just everything is decently good
column41: until the encouragement of "Pay-to-Play" and bad design choices on terms of coding that made this game fall to the mixed status it is in now."

reviewText:
Steak & Ale Pie
Heat the oil in the pan with the onion and garlic for 1 minute.

Add the steak. Cook until the meat is seared all over and there is no pink left.

Pour in half the Ale and allow to simmer for a minute, then pour in the rest with the thyme, chilli powder salt and pepper.

Crumble in the oxo cubes- both the beef and the vegetables. Add in the chopped vegetables.

Simmer for 10 mintues and then transfer to a large casserole pot. If the gravy doesnt cover the meat then add some water and mix in.

Pop the dish into the oven at gas mark 3 or 4 and leave for at least 1 hour 30 mins.

20 minutes before you want to serve, roll out the pastry and cut appropriate size tops for your pie dishes.

Take the dish out of the oven and ladel the meat into the individual dishes.

Pop on the tops on the dishes and put back in the oven for 20 mins (gas 4). You could make one large pie using the casserole disk if desiered.

Enjoy!

reviewText:
Where to start with AVA... well it used to be good!  I would highly suggest playing it if you like competitive shooters and free to play ones at that but with all the negative directions this game has gone down the past few years I cant imagine it staying afloat much longer.

The bad:
- Timed weapons so you end up having to pay $ for good/the best items
- Most of the maps are unimaginative
- The worst anti cheat system I have ever experienced

I'll give this a good recommendation for what it used to be not what it has become.

Been playing this sincce ijji had it, back then it was a blast but nowadays when AG (AeriaGames) took over it kinda goes up and down. Really good but it's kinda turned into a P2W game and everybody hates that, nobody can disagree to that.

Cons

Rating

reviewText:
They call it Free2Play; I call it Free until you reach the point where you realize you need to put in real money to make any meaningful progress.
The first 10 levels was fun, especially in the Beginner Channel which is limited to level 1-5/1-10. Next, you're in the Public Channel without level limits; the territory of people who dedicate serious time and real money. Later on, trying to earn game money is almost pointless, so you'll have to put in real money if you want to buy stuff and stay competitive. It'd be better if there were more level specific Channels like 1-15; 1-20; etc. Be prepared to get insta-killed... a lot.
You will run into hackers. If you press ESC during a game, it shows three things: disconnect; cancel; REPORT HACKER. That shows how much of an issue it is.
Auto Balance is terrible. It balances the amount of players, but not individual scores.
Unrelated, but there was one time where some fool had an AK that kills you with only one shot... in the leg. We still won.

reviewText:
I've played AVA since it first came out in 2006.

Firstly to all of you who have loved and played the classic AVA for years and then came on Steam only to see bad reviews and are confused, ALL the bad reviews are from ignorant people who just downloaded and uninstalled the game for some promotion, and more bad reviews by bitter people who were disappointed that AVA stopped giving out permanent weapons for free so easily because of moving from ijji to Aeria... yes that's right you can STILL get permamnent weapons for free, just use the capsule shop for blue money! Anyway games like PlanetSide 2 are even worse for being strict on weapons, it is so P2W. AVA is not P2W, and even if you want to pay it's not expensive.

For people who haven't played AVA and are thinking about it, I highly recommend it. AVA is extremely lightweight for such a seemingly heavy game, so it is good for most non-gaming computers too, I used to play it all the time on a rubbish computer. I'ts programming is good and very enjoyable to play, it's one of the only first-person shooter games where I get 200+FPS. I love AVA it's a pure classic, I highly recommend it. Convoy Runaway is my favourite mode on it, and there are so many different maps and modes there is something for everyone to enjoy...

Bottom line AVA is a great game, it should be respected and given better consideration big time. I enjoy this game more than PlanetSide 2, PlanetSide 2 is too focused on one game mode of map domination, when u just want really fun arcade kill em up modes AVA is for you. I especially like it A LOT more than TF2, personally I really dislike TF2.

Rate this review up so that everyone can actually see a fair and original review instead of the hundreds of TF2 players who all write EXACTLY the same thing! e.g. 1 install 2. get knife for tf2, 3 uninstall... lololol

reviewText: Alliance of Valiant Arms is an example of a Pay2Win game. By spending an average amount, you get so much stuff, it will easily over-power anyone who has payed nothing. The sniper rifles are extremely cheap. When using a sniper rifle, once a shot is fired, you can switch to another weapon and then switch back by quickly hitting the q button twice, its like an OP DMR that can one shot anyone under any circumstances. It takes too much time to rank up, and you cannot purchase anything until Rank 8. This will have you stuck with default items for ages.  And the ONE thing that made me quit this game is none other than the god forsaken time trails!!! They suck, they are impractical, and just ruins your day when all of your weapons suddenly dissapear. Otherwise, the game is decent in every other perspective. The graphics are nice, controls are smooth, maps and gamemodes are acceptable and even unique in some cases, like Escape (Though Zombie modes suck). Without those, the only thing it has running for it is that its not Combat Arms.

reviewText:
One of, if not THE best FPS games in existance.

One of, if not THE worst gaming community in existance.

Statistically 7/10 players use third party software to cheat. Although it is an NA/EU game, roughly 50% of the player base is not from that region. roughly 90% of them are self absorbed ego maniac's with zero care for anything other than themselve's, who literally feel the need to insult every human alive in a futile attempt to make themselves feel better.

The game itself is amazing to say the least, despite what Aeria has done to it, and despite the putridly toxic community inhabiting it. It has a very steep learning curve, being simple for anyone to pick up and enjoy, while difficult enough to shame even the most veteran FPS player.

I have been playing this game since Open Beta, and despite a small leave of absence due to Aeria's blunder's(perm weapon removal, perms are back now though), I am certain i will be playing this game until the option to do so is no longer available.

A note to those new player's: ignore the majority of the community, they will intentionally steer you wrong, and attempt to offend you. and for the love of all that is holy, do not expect a CS clone. this game has actual physics with realistic ballistic's. but beware, while your bullets will land within your crosshair, that is not to say your crosshair will not be the size of the screen and shaking ferociously.

reviewText:
I played this game in the summer of 2011.
But, not on steam.
On Aeria Games (or that's how I think you spell it)

Anyway, when I first played this game, I instantly thought it was Pay2Win.
It was.

But, I gave this game a try. I played this game for hours.
I forgot it was Pay2Win because I played so many events and I earned so many Euros(but mostly from people helping me out, also Euros are in-game money).
______________________________________________________________________
Why was it Pay2Win?

You had to REPAIR your gun. (costs money)
You had to RENT the most OP guns. (costs money)
You always fought EXTREME PROFESSIONALS ALL THE TIME (well, it really depends).
______________________________________________________________________
Don't get me started on infection mode.
Infection mode is basically zombies (players) vs. other players.
It was SO hard to kill one single zombie. I wasted all my ammo on one single zombie every game.
You couldn't even kill someone as a zombie, so many PROFESSIONALS ._.

There is a rank system, and it was rare to encounter a horrible high-ranked player.
Also, there were lots of hackers back then.
______________________________________________________________________

I forgot all about this game.
Now there are people complaining about how Aeria Games ruined this awful game even more.
Playing this game to get my free TF2 knife brought back memories.

I couldn't enjoy them because of the PROFESSIONALS.

reviewText:
Edit #2: Paid armor has become almost an absolute necessity at this point since it is the only thing that negates aimpunch, an extremely annoying game mechanic. Weapons are still unbalanced, just like some of the free guns are. Lag is much more noticable with full ~1 second delays. Still fun to play casually though I wouldn't reccomend getting competitive since that requires good servers(lol) and lots of $$.

Edit: So in a recent patch permanent guns have made a return (though they never should've left in the first place). This means new players will have access to the game's top tier guns for free immediately which is a pretty good thing. The game could still use some major weapon balancing and should provide easier means of obtaining armor. Servers aren't the best but its not too big of an issue.

The game was real fun when it was first founded, there were permanent weapons that could be bought with ingame currency. Gameplay was pretty balanced and didn't have all the pay2win stuff it did now after being hosted by a new company (aeria). I wouldn't recommend playing this anymore as it really requires you to pay in order to keep up with others. Even if you could afford spending money on this game, I still think it would be a waste and that money could be better spent on other games worth your time.
voteText: 4 of 4 people (100%) found this review helpful

reviewText:
OverviewGameplay: 9/10
Sounds: 7/10
Multiplayer: 5/10
Graphics: 7/10

Pros & Cons+ Wide selection of weapons
+ First F2P FPS game to introduce permenant weapons (disregarding the transition from Ijji to Aeria)
+ Tons of different game modes
+ Very solid shooting mechanics
+ Above average voice acting
+ Quality Co-op
+ Good map design
+ Optimized very well
- Awful anti-cheat (tons of hackers)
- Low player base
- Pay to win to an extent

ConclusionAvA has been around since the early 2000s, and is still somewhat active today. Theres a reason why other newer F2P FPS games died out, like Soldier Front 2, and Fear online, the gun play is just bad in both. In my opinion AvA has one of the most solid shooting mechanics in any F2P FPS game to date. Some may argue this is not the case, but with the rampant hackers, awful community, why stick around in AvA? AvA has come a long way since beta, it even changed publishers (for the worse, rest in peace Ijji), but is still a fun game to play once in a while. The hit detection is solid, and the lag compensation is well coded. One of my favorite gamemodes is escort, which is one of the most innovative and fun gamemodes

7/10

reviewText:
An honest Q&A. >UPDATE NOTES BELOW*

-What is AVA?
Free to Play FPS game with good graphics compared to other F2P shooters.

-Is it Pay2Win?
The new gamemode Lastman gives new players the opportunity to get better weapons even without spending real money. And skill is an important factor. So basically no. Unless you see some uber cashers who got rare weapons.

-Are there many hackers out there?
I see not many hackers. Even tho everyone in the lobby is spamming prefire haxx" "thro the smoke! Haaaaacjjerrrr" Don't believe them.. Just some butthurt flamers.

-Is it better than CS:GO?
Just try it. Get into it and see for yourself. Thats a matter of opinion.

-Do I get a virus by downloading the game?
Nope. The andicheat software may cause false alarm for Norton or some other stupid antiviruses. But c-mon. Which gamer uses Norton.

reviewText: Do not listen to the special promotion for the TF2 item; Not only does this game suck in almost every way imaginable, but the achievements themselves don't even work. It is easily not worth the Black Rose and this game is literally more difficult to look at then to play. This is the worst example of a shooter I have seen in a long time; It is Pay2Win, begs you to buy its overpriced ingame credits to buy weapon reskins and extremely overpowered buffs and weapons and steals from other bad games like Call of Duty. The major design flaw in this game is the concept itself, and Valve should feel ashamed to link a Team Fortress 2 promotion to this pile of raw waste. I can see the appeal this game would have to some people with a far below average IQ, but it doesn't hold up to people that want to actually have fun with their games. The added fact that this game uses a far inferior cheat protection system that allows hackers in every server and servers that openly boast HACKERS PLAY HERE" just makes it even worse. Waste of time

To say this game has coop is insulting, it was so repetative that I didn't even want to play more than 1 macth of the coop, If i want good coop I would go play Payday 2 sure it costs money to buy it but at least it works with no problems and is fun. reviewText:
The textbook definition of Pay-to-Win. Very few weapons are permanant now. That means that you're paying real-life money for in-game items that quickly expire.
Now, a few years back when the game was still with it's original company, Ijji, I think, there was very few microtransactions and those that did exist didn't give paying players upper hands against those that didn't.
Aside from all that, the game is genuienly fun to play, and can take a good amount of skill to compete with noobs that spent $20 for the most overpowered gun in the game, only for it to last 30 days.
Lastly, the game installs a (I've heard of it referred to as a rootkit?) hacking-prevention program that stays on your stystem even after deleting the game, called GameGuard. You have to rummage through your system 32 or 64 files to delete it, and that's crossing the line.
I remember a time where I enjoyed this game, enjoyed ranking, playing, and saving up in game currency for a shiny new assault rifle.
You get a TF2 knife. I guess that's a plus.
3/10.
Feel free to try the game. Not recommended as it's more work to uninstall, but it's your decision.

reviewText:
I've played since IJJI had the game, so my playtime doesn't reflect the hours I've put down.
Honestly.. I don't think much has changed. I haven't seen the hackers people are complaining about. The hitreg is the same as it ever was. The shop.. I can see why people would be miffed, but at the same time, I like the idea of it. You're not just stuck with a bad weapon (else reselling it for only a fraction of the original price) anymore after paying full price for permanent. At the same time you're not stuck with a -good- weapon because permanent exists only for select guns, so there's that. But the game keeps throwing good timed guns at me for free and supply crates are pretty easy to get, so that part is pretty cool.

I like the idea behind the tickets in the capsule shop, but it only streamlines the process of getting premium guns.. it doesn't make it easier. 3/4 years on I still want a VSS Katana, and I'm no closer. This part bothers me.

But yeah. If you can look past these things, you do have a good game. A game that I will continue to play. With AP earned mostly from free offers.

reviewText: This was originally an extremely fun game with amazing gunplay, with fantastic physics, hit detection, progression systems, and player customization. In fact, before I downloaded the game via steam, I had logged over 1000 hours playing via the game launcher. But that was four years ago. In the past two years, it has been completely demolished into one of the most horrible cash-hounding games in history by a takeover from a terrible game host named Aeria Games. All this company does is try to profit in any way possible, whether it be from making originially permanent guns timed, shoving horrendous AP offers in your face, or trying to create a shop system where it is impossible to play the game without buying AP. In a recent update, every single gun in the shop is timed if you wish to play with in-game currency, meaning that you will farm for hours upon hours on end and save every single euro just to see your gun quickly expire until you spend 20$ of real cash for each new gun. The bottom line is, this game was made into an intrinsic pay to play game by an extremely greedy developer. I do not recommend this game, not just because I don't recommend supporting the host, but because the host has literally ruined the game's overall balance and fluidity.\n\nEDIT: The host, Aeria Games, is still extremely greedy and shoves cash offers in the most insane places, but the good news is they finally got SOME semblance of sense and brought back permanent weapons purchasable with in-game money. Now, these weapons are almost twice as expensive in some cases as they were before Aeria Games took over, but at least you don't have to spend any real money. I would recommend playing this game for the gunplay and the community, learning the recoil patterns and unique feel of each distinct gun can be a lot of fun. It is definitely not a spray and pray game like Call of Duty, and the ranks, progression, and supply points (for in-game currency) add a level of progression that provides an incentive to keep you playing that Counter-Strike does not have. However, I would still not spend any real money on this game, as every cash offer is a major rip-off.

reviewText:
Everything in AVA is now relatively balanced, so it's beginner friendly. Every gun in the shop is now permanent and the hacker problem is mostly solved. The servers are still pretty bad, but the community did improve. The game itself is different from other games, so I would give it a try.


Previous Review:
AVA has become a pay to win game and I do not recommend it to new starters. I mean there are good permanent guns out there, but half the weapon shop is full of timed weapons. If you're willing to spend hundreds of dollars into this game than go for it, but in my opinion it's not worth your time and money. I would rather play other fps games like CS:GO. If you're not willing to spend money on any games then be my guest, play AVA. If you're willing to pay at least 20 dollars into this game, just buy CS:GO. The community is horrible and hating, the games infested with hackers (hacking rates increases when Aeria does something wrong), and the servers are trash. Why start and pay money in this game if you can just buy another game and not waste your time. I hope this review helped you see another perspective in this game. Don't get me wrong, I love this game, but I'm starting to slide to CS:GO seeing how everything is going down.

reviewText: This was originally an extremely fun game with amazing gunplay, with fantastic physics, hit detection, progression systems, and player customization. In fact, before I downloaded the game via steam, I had logged over 1000 hours playing via the game launcher. But that was four years ago. In the past two years, it has been completely demolished into one of the most horrible cash-hounding games in history by a takeover from a terrible game host named Aeria Games. All this company does is try to profit in any way possible, whether it be from making originially permanent guns timed, shoving horrendous AP offers in your face, or trying to create a shop system where it is impossible to play the game without buying AP. In a recent update, every single gun in the shop is timed if you wish to play with in-game currency, meaning that you will farm for hours upon hours on end and save every single euro just to see your gun quickly expire until you spend 20$ of real cash for each new gun. The bottom line is, this game was made into an intrinsic pay to play game by an extremely greedy developer. I do not recommend this game, not just because I don't recommend supporting the host, but because the host has literally ruined the game's overall balance and fluidity.\n\nEDIT: The host, Aeria Games, is still extremely greedy and shoves cash offers in the most insane places, but the good news is they finally got SOME semblance of sense and brought back permanent weapons purchasable with in-game money. Now, these weapons are almost twice as expensive in some cases as they were before Aeria Games took over, but at least you don't have to spend any real money. I would recommend playing this game for the gunplay and the community, learning the recoil patterns and unique feel of each distinct gun can be a lot of fun. It is definitely not a spray and pray game like Call of Duty, and the ranks, progression, and supply points (for in-game currency) add a level of progression that provides an incentive to keep you playing that Counter-Strike does not have. However, I would still not spend any real money on this game, as every cash offer is a major rip-off.

reviewText:
A.V.A is a wierd mix of serious play while still being casual at the same time.

Powered by Unreal, something should impress you. The engine allows for a wider varriety in game modes, while still being somewhat realistic. Graphics are also well done.

For gameplay, there isn't a whole lot to talk about. There gun rental system isn't really a rental. You purchase the gun, and have to pay for repairs. There's wave based games, escape, TDM, bomb defusing, survival, and COOP modes. You should be able to find something that fits your play.

The big bonus is that this game isn't a pay 2 win title. Sure it has paid items, but they don't blow anything you can buy in game out of the water. That should be the most noted thing with this title, it's the least play 2 win out of all F2P titles. Skill counts here.

I don't remember any bad experiences with the game, hackers aren't everywhere, game is fairly clean.

7/10 - Something fresh, looks good, and worth playing.

reviewText:
A.V.A is a fantastic free-2-play first person shooter! Launched in 2007 in Korea, and published in NA/EU in 2009, A.V.A has remained a graphical beast that trumps all F2P comeptitors! Utilizing the Unreal Engine 2.5, A.V.A delivers a unique style of game play, along with brisk graphical detail.

Casual and competitive players will find a home in this action packed first person shooter! From Battle Gear: Beginz, to crazed zombies, and other fun game modes, you and your friends will enjoy every moment played! Tons of unique weapon skins, and dozens of gear to customize your characters appearance, and personality!

For those competitive minded players, A.V.A offers its own built-in matchmaking and ranking system, called the Clan Championships. Solo Que, and Team Que, all with rated play based on RP! Get your team of 5, or brigade your own path to the top of the rankings! Rewards, and plenty of opportunities await the strongest of competitors!

Third-party support is also strong with the likes of fabled host, ESL, and A.V.A-unique CGO! Check both these wonderful leagues out for the best of the best competition! If that's still enough there's also the international IeSF and AIC events once a year, where teams from both NA, and EU are flown out for free to compete in international tournaments in Korea, Japan, and China!

Dozens of features are included in the game, ranging from first person spectate, practice rooms, spectator mode, and tons of other options to provide you with the best gaming experience possible!

There are a range of negatives, that detract from the game itself however! All guns are timed for 30 days at outrageous prices ($20 for 30-Days each month). The value in spending money in A.V.A is non-existent. There's a large disparity between the good guns, and the bad guns. Do not spend money in A.V.A in its current state! Spend it elsewhere!

F2P FPS: 8/10
FPS: 7/10

reviewText:
Awsome like COD online but a lot better. This one is actuly updated and 100% freeer. (edit) Its slipped a lot since then, its overdone the p2w thing, and the overall game quality has slipped. no longer reccomending, not worth the download anymore. Though if you download for the tf2 knife its worth trying to see if you like it for a short period but dont waste long on it and also i suspect they have powered down the servers as the game is generally more laggy and slower, also when aeria took over instead of fixing a glitch they just closed the map as it was a co-op level and the glitch allowed people to get an item as a f2p player that they intended only p2p players to be able to get, thats the ethos aeria has money. The game overall now feels (the europe+usa version at least) that it is only still running to squeeze the remaining money out of the remaining core players.

ALSO SOME ADVICE: If you have ever installed this game then uninstalled and have no intent of playing again or playing another game that uses game guard, the games anti-cheat engine, which is ironically a minor security threat dosent uninstall, if a hacker tried to get into your pc they could make it a threat so i would advise googling how to propery uninstall gameguard. While you have the game installed this is not a problem because it will update, but once the game is uninstalled it will not update if new security risks emerge so could become a problem.

Edit, ava has recently been acuired by a new company that bought areia, will see if anything changes and update this review if any significant changes come to my attention. (edit) Nope.

reviewText:
I've played this game since its IJJI days (the original publisher), and I still continue to play now, even thought IJJI has been bought by Aeria Games.

Anyway, this game used to get a lot of flak for being P2W" and for being dead because Aeria Games removed all the permanent weapons. That's about half-true now.

With the latest patch
date: Aeria Games has FINALLY brought back permanent weapons to the Euro Shop
recommended: meaning that by playing the game
hoursPlayed: you can earn Euros (which is the in-game currency) which you can use to purchase weapons off the Euro Shop. Once you buy one
voteText: it's yours. Forever. No renting ‚ô•‚ô•‚ô•‚ô•‚ô•‚ô•‚ô•t. Once you purchase a gun
helpfulPercent: you are able to purchase mods for it (make it more accurate
votesHelpful: a higher rate of fire
votesFunny: which degrade with use along with the gun. You can
column16: repair your guns with Euros and re-purchase mods if they break/wear down.\n\nEuros are fairly easy to get as a new player. Every day you log into the game
column17: you can complete daily missions for a game mode of your choice
column19: there are events hosted every once in a while
column20:
such as "Play *some map* for *some amount of time* and receive *some Euros*.")

Now to the ugly side of the game.

Hackers are a bit common
column21: since this game uses the XIGNCODE3 anti-cheat
column22: which is horrible IMO. (There is an in-game report button you can use
column23: and there is also a "report form" on the official A.V.A. website you can submit to Aeria when you want to report someone)\n\nThis game is nowhere near as P2W as it used to be
column24: given that Aeria is mainly releasing re-skins of existing weapons.\n\nOverall
column25: I'd recommend you give this game a try.\n\nI still enjoy it
column26:
and I hope you do as well.


P.S. There is a Welcome Package you can purchase for A.V.A. from the official game website for 9 AP
column27: which is equivalent to 9 cents. This package gives you 4 permanent guns (a good sniper
column34: and timed characters (which have a different look and give you a bit more EXP when used).\n\nAgain
column35: the Welcome Package is 9 CENTS. (You can only receive it if you are spending AP with Aeria Games for the FIRST time. There is a way to get AP for free
column38: etc. I myself recommend watching the videos and tabbing out
column39: as it's the easiest way to get free AP.)"

reviewText:
This game is surprisingly good for a free FPS game!

I originally downloaded it a few months ago to get the black rose spy knife thing from getting the first achievement, but the game was broken for me, so I couldn't play it until they finally fixed the installer.  I played this all morning and had a blast!  The combat feels more like a watered-down Call of Duty game, but it's not like you paid anything to play it!  I didn't really notice any lag, even though I had 220+ ms ping since I was playing at 4 AM my time, which meant I was automatically connected to European servers.  Sniping was really fun, and I'd say it ranks up to stomping 1.6 pubbers, since people panic when there's an actual sniper that can aim!

There's basically 3 classes - Point, Rifle, and Sniper.  The point character gets the heavier weaponry, and is meant to be the squad leader-type (heading the front).  Rifle guy is the 'CS' archetype since he has the M4A1 and AK47 weapons.  The Sniper is basically a Scout-user with AWP-sounds.  It takes 2-3 hits to kill anyone (depending on if they bought armor), although a headshot is a one-hit kill.  There's a cash shop thing inside the game, but I don't think anyone spends actual money on a game like this, so there really isn't a downside if you only spend in-game credits over actual cash.  You can buy new grenades (like flashbangs!) in the shop, but everything has a durability price so that you keep playing forever.  None of the items for me expired in the several hours I spent testing this game out.

There are about 7 game types, I think, ranging from Deathmatch style to L4D-types.  Obviously there's also CT vs Terrorists bomb defusal game-type as well as a horde mode game-type.  The robot horde mode was the first thing I played, and it actually impressed me when you actually got to the boss LOL.  I thought it was easy as heck, until my party of 4 reached the boss, and it was a gigantic mech straight out of something like Vanquish.

The regular DM maps are pretty bland, but it's still fun to play in!  It's a free game, so I can't really complain because it was actually really fun to play even though I had no idea what I was doing.  It's a pretty easy game, but if you and your friends have nothing better to do and want to play an FPS game, you might as well give this thing a shot since it's free.

TL;DR
This is a fun Call of Duty/Counter-Strike/Left4Dead clone, but free2play and has a non-intrusive cash shop to actual gameplay.  Play it if you're bored and feel like dicking around in another FPS game~

reviewText:
Timed weapons, lack of publisher support, and Brazilian overload. Flooded with hispanics and Brazilians, and although I have nothing against them, they are a terrible community of gamers. They have terrible ping. Then there's Aeria Games, whose greed basically overrides any sense of progress in the game's development. Aeria even stooped as far as to change one of the features that made this game good: permanent weapons. This feature set the game above most if not all other F2P FPS games out there, and Aeria took this away because of greed.

Overall, I'd rate this game 9/11, would Jihad again.

EDIT:

They brought back permanent weapons. Still wouldn't recommend it though.

reviewText: This is by far the best free-to-play games I've ever played. I played this back in 2010-11 was around the first time I played it, I didn't understand the game all that well and everything like that so I stopped playing it for a long long time. I watched my friend play this game and I thought I'd give it a shot and it's not actually one of those average pay to win games. Hell lol I've played 19 hours in the past two weeks and the second weeks just getting started lol. I'm actually probably gonna go play some after I finish writing this but anyway. The only problem I have with this game is when you spend money on it, which I've spent maybe $15 when you purchase something you may or may not get it. Which if you don't you are supposed to contact them which I did Sunday and today is now Tuesday and I have not gotten a response yet. That's with most average games you won't hear a response until probably two weeks? I'll try to update this and let you all know when I get a response and how the service was. In my opinion I would say that you would not have to spend money on this game what so ever, it's a fantastic game itself. What I mean by this is you can earn AP which is what you can spend and earn the credits it's called AP (Aeria Points) but anyway you can earn that by doing surveys... I know it sounds hard but you can actually do them quiet easy if you know what you're doing. You can earn about 60-100 AP for each survey for free?? I've done it... It works yes. Now back to you don't necessarily have to spend money on this game because when you play the game modes it doesn't matter which one but you earn euro which you can spend to buy weapons, equipment, ect. PLUS in some of the game modes not all of them they give you a free loot box reward I would call it. You can open it right after the match and it can give you grenades, pistols, armor, ect. I actually got lucky off one of those and got a sick glock which is better than all the pistols I had anyway there's also the Aeria Ignite application that you can get and every 12 hours you can open a loot box too that gives you random items. I got dual berettas permanent which was awesome... I just got them so I haven't tried them yet. When you level up you can get free items too like permanent weapons or get a 14 day armor something. That's what I do like about this game though how they give you weapons that last a few days sure that sucks right but that gives you a chance to try the weapon out and get the feel of it in case if you do want to buy it. I'm an older player and they didn't used to have this but now they have like red and blue tickets? These tickets get you permanent guns and stuff too for free. Free you say? how? well back to those free rewards when playing matches or the Aeria Ignite application those cases drop red and blue tickets as well. More blue than red tickets but there's not that much of difference they both offer different permanent guns to buy. I've been playing this game for almost two weeks and I almost got enough red and blue tickets to buy a permanent gun each. Enough talk about the you do not have to pay to win feature let's talk about the gameplay. It's fantastic there's plenty of game modes to choose from. Say you want to play with bots or you want to play against zombies (infected) with your friends or say you want to be the zombie and come after your friend! There's to many different game modes to play in this game to name them. To be honest they're still adding new game modes! Like this tank game mode I haven't tried yet I've been focusing too much on getting my level up lol. It takes a while to level up but you get these boosters out of those loot boxes or if you do those surveys (offers) you can buy a booster for 9 AP which is cheap asf. It's only a one time purchase though lol but you can still get the boosters from the loot boxes. I purchased the xp booster for 9 AP and it started out with what 200% boost. Then I when into a boosting ex game mode then it went up to 340%. Then LOL I unboxed in one of those loot boxes a 400% xp boost... When I applied that and went back to that game mode I went up to 645%. I have no idea where the extra 5% came from but I am not complaining! Anyway this is my game fo life! I hope you all enjoy it as much as I am! PS. I'll see y'all on the battle field I'm going to play right now byes XD

reviewText: I truely like this first person shooter game, I've played it for countless hours. People say this game is only for the knife, but the knife for TF2 isn't event that good, cmon. Although the AeriaGames version is one of the worst versions, you should try Alliance of Valiant Arms on Garena (or Japan/Taiwan/Korea if you live in one of the countries). And of course, I do hate the things that cost money (kind of pay to win) and the fact that the average player would kick the noobs (obviously). This game is fun when there are lots of lobbies in gamemodes such as PVP, QuickMatch and CO-OP, but from my perspective, it's  starting to get boring as there aren't as much as QuickMatch and co-op games as before.\n\nThe TF2 knife is bad.

reviewText: This game is bad. For one, the tutorial is completely broken, as I was never able to complete the first objective. Another thing that is broken is the sound. I could rarely hear sound from bullets and such, because there was none. Third, it dosen't allow Fullscreen mode, which I will always put up in FPS games. Although I think we all know the reason we all got this game: for the Black Rose spy knife in TF2.

reviewText: I just played this game to get a Team Fortress 2 promotional item, but I did play the game for at least an hour to get an idea of how well the game was made; it was pretty bad. I've been told that it has been updated, but I doubt it has really improved by a lot. The game has relatively good graphics but displeasing gameplay. Killing people is extremely easy which makes killing unimpressive and unsatisfying. Players in this game tend to be very horrible at first-person shooters, making winning for your team almost effortless. The upgrades on your weapons make your player even more over-powered, as you receive extremely beneficial upgrades on your weapons whereas other players still have default un-upgraded weapons. This makes playing even more easier. The gamemodes almost mimic Counter-Strike and I would daresay this game is merely just a low-funded copy of Counter-Strike. I would not recommend this game unless you're seriously bored and craving to dominate other players... the fun in this game can only last so long.

reviewText: Despite being Free to Play, AVA is a well-made game. It is a solely-multiplayer war-themed shooter, with extremely noticable similarities to Counter-Strike. There are a few different gameplay modes to choose from, such as a free-for-all shooting match, team-based deathmatch, and a save-the-hostages mode. It parts ways with Counter-Strike with the in-game store, where you acquire gold and experience, and use it to buy new weapons and items, similar to what you might find in a game like Call of Duty.\nThe game does fall short in communication, making it rather difficult to communicate with your teammates and help each other out. In addition, aside from the buyable weapons, there is little customizability. There are only three classes to choose from when playing, though each class has a large variety of weapons to choose from. The maps are also fairly similar, and don't cater to all classes. All-in-all though, it's like a free version of Counter-Strike, and worth a try.

reviewText:
This game is NOT pay to win.

I really don't understand why people are complaining about overpowered real-money-weapons.

Yes,
there are improved versions of the weapons you can purchase with the ingame currency,
but these are generally (with some exeptions, these weapons are really pretty op, but rarely seen) slight improvements like shooting a little bit faster, or having 2 more bullets per magazine etc. .

And yes,
there are weapons that you can only buy with AP or red tickets,
but you can also obtain red tickets by playing the game and a little bit of luck, if you really want these other weapons.

Also, if you are a new player, you get tons of free weapons (some timed, some perm) and ingame currency if you level up.

But at the end, it is still the player, and not the weapon, who decides wether you play well or not. If you are good, you can crush a player that got full AP weapons and armor with your ingame-currency weapon. A headshot is still a headshot, no matter what weapon you use.

reviewText:
This game is great; I've described the feeling you have after playing it below:







Depression is a state of low mood and aversion to activity that can affect a person's thoughts, behavior, feelings and sense of well-being.[1][2] People with depressed mood can feel sad, anxious, empty, hopeless, helpless, worthless, guilty, irritable, ashamed or restless. They may lose interest in activities that were once pleasurable, experience loss of appetite or overeating, have problems concentrating, remembering details or making decisions, and may contemplate, attempt or commit suicide. Insomnia, excessive sleeping, fatigue, aches, pains, digestive problems or reduced energy may also be present.[3] Depressed mood is a feature of some psychiatric syndromes such as major depressive disorder,[2] but it may also be a normal reaction to life events such as grief, a symptom of some bodily ailments or a side effect of some drugs and medical treatments.

CausesLife events
Adversity in childhood, such as grief, neglect, mental abuse, and unequal parental treatment of siblings can contribute to depression in adulthood.[4][5] Childhood physical or sexual abuse in particular significantly increases the likelihood of experiencing depression over the life course.[6]

Life events and changes that may precipitate depressed mood include childbirth, menopause, financial difficulties, job problems, a medical diagnosis (cancer, HIV, etc.), bullying, loss of a loved one, natural disasters, social isolation, relationship troubles, jealousy, separation, and catastrophic injury.[7][8] Adolescents may be especially prone to experiencing depressed mood following social rejection.[9]

Medical treatments
Certain medications are known to cause depressed mood in a significant number of patients. These include interferon therapy for hepatitis C,[10] medications for high blood pressure and sleep inducing pills. [11]

Non-psychiatric illnesses
Main article: Depression (differential diagnoses)
Depressed mood can be the result of a number of infectious diseases, nutritional deficiencies, neurological conditions [12] and physiological problems, including hypoandrogenism (in men), Addison's disease, Lyme disease, multiple sclerosis, chronic pain, stroke,[13] diabetes,[14] and cancer.[15]

Psychiatric syndromesMain article: Depressive mood disorders
A number of psychiatric syndromes feature depressed mood as a main symptom. The mood disorders are a group of disorders considered to be primary disturbances of mood. These include major depressive disorder (MDD; commonly called major depression or clinical depression) where a person has at least two weeks of depressed mood or a loss of interest or pleasure in nearly all activities; and dysthymia, a state of chronic depressed mood, the symptoms of which do not meet the severity of a major depressive episode. Another mood disorder, bipolar disorder, features one or more episodes of abnormally elevated mood, cognition and energy levels, but may also involve one or more episodes of depression.[16] When the course of depressive episodes follows a seasonal pattern, the disorder (major depressive disorder, bipolar disorder, etc.) may be described as a seasonal affective disorder.

Outside the mood disorders: borderline personality disorder often features an extremely intense depressive mood; adjustment disorder with depressed mood is a mood disturbance appearing as a psychological response to an identifiable event or stressor, in which the resulting emotional or behavioral symptoms are significant but do not meet the criteria for a major depressive episode;[17]:355 and posttraumatic stress disorder, an anxiety disorder that sometimes follows trauma, is commonly accompanied by depressed mood.[18] Depression is sometimes associated with substance use disorder. Both legal and illegal drugs can cause substance use disorder.[19]

AssessmentQuestionnaires and checklists such as the Beck Depression Inventory or the Children's Depression Inventory can be used by a mental health provider to detect and assess the severity of depression.[20]

TreatmentDepressed mood may not require any professional treatment, and may be a normal reaction to certain life events, a symptom of some medical conditions, or a side effect of some drugs or medical treatments. A prolonged depressed mood, especially in combination with other symptoms, may lead to a diagnosis of a psychiatric or medical condition which may benefit from treatment.[21] Different sub-divisions of depression have different treatment approaches.[22] In the United States, it has been estimated that two thirds of people with depression do not actively try to receive treatment.[23]

The UK National Institute for Health and Care Excellence (NICE) 2009 guidelines indicate that antidepressants should not be routinely used for the initial treatment of mild depression, because the risk-benefit ratio is poor.[24]

Sex differencesThere are a number of symptoms that are used to help diagnose depression. Looking at all instances of depression that can be confirmed (i.e. psychological help is obtained or a suicide occurs from depression-related circumstances), a one-author report[25] states that women have a higher rate of major depression than men, but looking at individual symptoms, the gender divide intensifies in some areas, disappears in some, and reverses in others. While women have a greater proportion of somatic symptoms, such as appetite, sleep disturbances and fatigue accompanied by pain and anxiety, than men, the gender difference is much smaller in other aspects of depression. Female respondents report twice the prevalence of somatic symptoms as male (2.8% vs. 1.4%) versus depression not associated with somatic symptoms (2.3% vs. 1.7%). Depression with somatic symptoms is highly likely to also have an anxiety disorder (31.4% vs. 22.9%), to have pain (60% vs. 48%), and to have chronic depression (49.2% vs. 36.8%). Men with depression with somatic symptoms were more likely than those without to have pain (48.9% vs. 28.6%) but were not more likely to have an anxiety disorder (39.3% vs. 31.9%) or chronic dysphoria (37.8% vs. 33.3%). Instances of suicide in men is much greater than in women. In a report by Lund University in Sweden and Stanford University, it was shown that men commit suicide at a rate almost three times that of women in Sweden, and the Centers for Disease Control and Prevention and National Center for Injury Prevention and Control report that the rate in the US is almost four times as many males as females.[26] However, women have higher rates of suicide ideation and attempts.[citation needed] The difference is attributed to men choosing more effective methods resulting in the higher rate of success.[27][28]

A problem in analyzing the results of mental health research and mental health statistics is the prevalence of reporting bias. Currently, the only way to collect data is to survey people and look at hospitalization rates. There are potential problems with people mis-reporting their feelings, the frequency of depressive and anxious thoughts, and other information that subjects might want to suppress
